column5: He passed away a year later from brain cancer. Brain was just so full of incredible intelligence & empathy it couldn‚Äôt contain him. I still write him sometimes. And of course, I‚Äôll teach my niece & nephew about typewriters, showing them how to make a ‚Äú!‚Äù just like he did.
I get that feeling sober sometimes tbh

I don‚Äôt want to alarm you, but I started hearing music and sounds above me like that, voices calling my name periodically, etc. and was dx‚Äôd with a psychotic disorder a few years later. It can definitely be an early sign of schizophrenia, especially if you‚Äôre in the 18-30 age range. Something to keep an eye on.

I think you greatly underestimate the affect being raised in an abusive and/or unsupportive home can have and the # of people who are affected by that.

This happened to me a LOT as a kid, like I went to bed with, to give an example, my favorite teddy bear, and it wasn‚Äôt there when I woke up. My parents would scour the house for the missing object but it would never be found. Even when we moved it never turned up. I still wonder what happened to them sometimes! And no, I didn‚Äôt have a dog and my brother was 10 years older so it would have been really weird and uncharacteristic for him to psychologically torment his baby sibling for kicks like that.

How is that not a plausible reason to change your name? Not saying it is in this case, but I think it‚Äôs fairly normal if not exactly ‚Äòcommon‚Äô for people to change their first and last names when they get married, especially if they have a poor relationship with their birth family.
What kind of phone does your mom have? Is it locked by passcode/fingerprint/face or could anyone access the camera? If locked, do your siblings know the passcode or otherwise have a way to access it?

I live with my mother. I‚Äôd have to be making at least 24k/year to live on my own comfortably around here, where a modest 1 bedroom apt can go over 1000/month easily not including utilities. Tough when you‚Äôre semi-disabled and a low-skilled worker with a GED, thats for sure. :/

I haven‚Äôt been to a meeting but I‚Äôm a member of a few online groups. I think I like their approach, generally. people in the groups seem more comfortable talking without fear of judgement compared to other similar ones like NAMI, which have a kind of rigid Western outlook on things imo. It does seem to be more focused on people who hear voices specifically and less the broad spectrum of psychotic/sz/sza experience, so I don‚Äôt know how helpful they are for me really as someone who sometimes but not regularly hears voices. but I like to hear other perspectives!

No DD date, entered non-filer information through the portal within a few hours of it going live on 4/10. It finally changed from ‚Äòpayment status not available‚Äô to ‚Äòyou are eligible for the payment‚Äô thursday evening. Still holding out hope it‚Äôll be here this coming week!

I‚Äôve been prescribed haloperidol and promethazine together multiple times over the years for intractable nausea/vomiting, never experienced or heard of interactions between the drugs. But to answer your question, no, I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre generally used together to sedate patients in the US? Haloperidol is kind of a last option antipsychotic period, from what I remember because the risk of TD is higher than modern antipsychotics. Where I live (new england) they just load patients up on so much Seroquel you can‚Äôt do much of anything except sleep.

Well first off I think it‚Äôs a good sign that you understand this is an issue. some people have zero self awareness, or the small amount they do have is so drowned out by their ego they can never confront it. It sounds pretty reasonable to think your disconnect with this side of yourself made your brain see it as a totally different entity, resulting in hallucinations. 
Do you have a psychologist or therapist you trust you‚Äôd be able to talk to about this? Full disclosure I‚Äôm just another crazy person but from what I know about ASPD disorders (not saying you have that, your story just reminded me of it) there‚Äôs no way to medicate your way out of low empathy, but various modalities of therapy can be really helpful. There are people who don‚Äôt experience empathy despite therapy and who have still been able to live moral lives and have relationships and not screw people over, because they made that decision. You can still know something without feeling it. It sounds like you know you don‚Äôt want to be some evil fucker. That‚Äôs a good start.

I wonder what the basis of the delusion is and why it‚Äôs so common!

Raised atheist but part culturally Jewish and part culturally Xtian, dabbled in paganism in middle and grade school, and in the past 8 years (26 now) I‚Äôve found myself drawn back to reconstructionist Judaism as a spiritual and not just cultural thing. I‚Äôm not observant, I don‚Äôt really  ‚Äòbelieve in‚Äô most traditional interpretations of G-d, but I enjoy connecting with my paternal ancestors through prayer/music/ritual/food when I have the opportunity.

Interesting question. I don‚Äôt feel like it made it ‚Äòbetter‚Äô or ‚Äòworse‚Äô, but I can imagine how it could trigger a bad trip or alternatively be a really helpful experience. Having a body period seems weird when you‚Äôre on psychedelics, at least to me.

Schizoaffective is just schizophrenic with a mood disorder as well. I doubt they are just saying it because of stigma, it‚Äôs just really common to have schizophrenia & mood issues like depression or bipolar.

That‚Äôs amazing! It‚Äôs so important for neuro-atypical kids to be able to see a future for themselves. You are helping their dreams come alive. And you have a really wonderful smile, it made me smile too :)

ECT should never be a first-line treatment, and a lot of mental health professionals and patients would agree it shouldn‚Äôt be a ‚Äòtreatment‚Äô at all. Weaning off antipsychotics would be a first step.

Why not? If 1% of people are schizophrenic and 3% are bipolar, many of whom have psychosis, plus all the people with psychotic depression and other conditions with psychosis as a symptom...if anything I would think the number would be a little higher.
I‚Äôm pretty sure the whole point of the theory is that it would happen BEFORE you die.

https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/unique-everybody-else/201810/does-dmt-model-the-near-death-experience


https://beckleyfoundation.org/2017/07/05/do-our-brains-produce-dmt-and-if-so-why/

I would agree there hasn‚Äôt been enough research, but there have been studies that measure the amount of DMT present in the human body, and it‚Äôs nowhere near the amount needed to cause a trip.

Eh, except that‚Äôs a purely speculative theory that hasn‚Äôt been backed up by science. From what we know, it would be impossible for the human body to produce enough DMT to cause an actual ‚Äòtrip‚Äô. It‚Äôs a nice idea, but chances are the only way you‚Äôre gonna have a DMT trip at the end of your life is if you inhale/ingest it from an outside source.

There‚Äôs no reason to think a history of psychosis would increase the likelihood of complications from COVID-19. Being a heavy smoker, however,  almost certainly does‚Äîbut you‚Äôre still more likely to die from lung cancer in 40 years then you are to die from coronavirus. The most recent numbers I can find say that 8 people total under the age of 30 have died out of over 200,000 cases, and most of those people had underlying health conditions. So it‚Äôs not ~impossible~, but extremely unlikely, that you would die from COVID-19 even if you are infected.

Had you had your levels tested pre-psychosis? Those levels could just be normal for you. In any case, low T usually isn‚Äôt something you need to worry about unless you‚Äôre experiencing actual symptoms. Having too high testosterone is much worse for you. It is odd to me that they tested your levels at all if you‚Äôre not taking supplemental testosterone, but if your doctor wasn‚Äôt worried I wouldn‚Äôt be either.

Where in the US are you? Is there a reason you can‚Äôt get on medicaid? In most states you‚Äôre eligible if you make under 133% of the poverty line (about 17,000/year). If not, try reaching out to your local Community Mental Health Center, or even someplace like Planned Parenthood might have recommendations.

Hallucinations aren‚Äôt synonymous with schizophrenia or psychosis. A lot of people have regular or occasional hallucinations (usually aural, but sometimes visual) and don‚Äôt have any kind of psychotic disorder‚Äîroughly 10% of the population from what I‚Äôve heard. Unless they have psychotic symptoms-and no, someone having different political opinions than you does not qualify as psychosis-they don‚Äôt have schizophrenia, at least if you‚Äôre going by DSM standards. And even if they do there‚Äôs no guarantee they would be dx‚Äôd with schizophrenia.
No, definitely not. It‚Äôs just a placebo‚Äîyou can get someone to pray over you for free and get the same effect.

I usually have at least an 8th and up to an oz in my checked luggage‚Äîdefinitely never go over an oz. Been flying at least 10 times a year for 7 years and never had an issue. Just use your head and make sure it‚Äôs packed discretely and there‚Äôs no discernible smell.

Methinks this guy is full of dog crap. Humans can‚Äôt get high by eating raw flower, there‚Äôs no physiological reason a dog would be able to. That makes sense, lack of sleep has a HUGE effect on frequency/intensity of hallucinations in people even without epilepsy. For what it‚Äôs worth, in my totally unprofessional opinion if the only schizophrenia symptoms you‚Äôre experiencing are hallucinations and feeling like someone is there when they aren‚Äôt, I‚Äôd be strongly inclined to think this has something to do with the epilepsy and not schizophrenia itself. People developing schizophrenia usually have drastic changes to their emotional and thought process. something to be aware of and watch out for though! Good luck, hope you can figure it out.

There is a definite connection‚Äîif you have one you‚Äôre up to 8X as likely to have the other‚Äîbut as far as I know science hasn‚Äôt been able to pinpoint exactly why. I wasn‚Äôt diagnosed with epilepsy but had at least one grand mal seizure a few months before being diagnosed with psychosis, possibly more smaller ones. Definitely something that would be worth talking to a neurologist about, if you have access to one-they‚Äôre likely to know more than a general practitioner. I‚Äôm sorry to hear you‚Äôre struggling with this on top of your seizures, that must be really hard to handle. 

Do you notice any correlation between the timing of your seizures and schizophrenia symptoms, like do you have these hallucinations soon after having seizures or no? Asking because I experienced my first audio hallucination just a few minutes before having my seizure.

When I‚Äôm in the middle of a psychotic episode it makes things worse, but on a day-to-day basis I‚Äôd say the benefits are greater than the negatives. I definitely don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs the great fountain of schizophrenic thought that a lot of people make it out to be, but everyone is different.
